question1a.value: 1. Children who have relatives trained in early childhood education have a better receptive vocabulary in English than children who do not have relatives trained in early childhood education.

question3a.value: the study not in an experimental setting, it is based on questionnaires with no manipulated variables.

question5a.value: Adults who trained in early childhood education will weigh early childhood education as more important compared to adults who did not receive training in early childhood education. Therefore people trained in early childhood education will focus more on the early education of their children or young relatives. Thus, we focus on testing the perceptive vocabulary in English using PPVT-R to find the relationship between children's vocabulary and their parent(s) education in early childhood education.

attributes.title: Fancy Tastes 2: Implicit and Explicit Perceptions of Class and Food

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Fancy Tastes 2: Implicit and Explicit Perceptions of Class and Food

other.value:
Exploratory Hypothesis 1: High social class individuals will have larger d scores on the IAT than low social class individuals.

Note: Social class will be operationalized as parental income and education

We will also be measuring perceived warmth (i.e., warmth, friendliness items) of these social class groups. We will not make any directional hypotheses in regards to this item.

sample.value: Estimating a medium effect size with power set at .95, 202 participants will be recruited for the study.

analyses.value:
Hypothesis 1: D scores for each IAT will be computed for the IAT using an open source code (Carpenter, et al., 2019). Larger D scores indicate stronger associations. 

Hypothesis 2: The following item, "In your opinion, how healthy are the diets of the following social groups" will be reverse-scored for both high and low social class groups, so that higher scores indicate a more unhealthy diet. T-tests will be used to test the difference in diet quality between high and low social class groups.

Hypothesis 3: Two items pertaining to competence (i.e., perceived competence and capability) will be reverse-scored for each social class group, then combined into one single composite score. Higher scores indicate less competence. T-tests will be used to test the difference in perceived competence between and low social class groups.

Hypothesis 4:  Two items pertaining to competence (i.e., perceived competence and capability) will be reverse-scored for each social class group, then combined into one single composite score. The scores for the low social class group will be subtracted from the scores of the high social class group; such that, higher scores indicate that low social class groups are seen as having less competence than high social class groups.

Pearson's correlations will be used to test the association between the "Class & Food" IAT d scores and the resulting sum of the explicit competence item.

outliers.value: Outliers were excluded following protocol described by Greenwald, et al. (2003). Open source R code is available through Dr. Carpenter and colleague's OSF page: https://osf.io/nf6vj/.

dependent.value:
Implicit Measures: 

Associations between Class & Food will be measured using one Implicit Association Task (Greenwald, McGhee, & Schwartz, 1998). In the "Class & Food" IAT, participants will be asked to sort 3 words pertaining to high & low social class (e.g., affluent, well-off; poor, broke: see https://osf.io/2apbe/) and 3 pairs of healthy & unhealthy foods item (e.g., raspberries, chocolate). Healthy and unhealthy food items are price-matched upon pre-testing.

Explicit Measures: 

Participants will be asked to rate how healthy the diets of high- and low-social class groups are using a 1-item measure: "On a scale from 1 (Eats very unhealthy) to 7 (Eats very healthy), please indicate how healthy are the diets of the following social groups". Participants will answer this question for high- and low-social class groups.

In addition, participants will be shown the following question: "Below are a number of statements with which you will agree or disagree. There are absolutely no right or wrong answers. Use the specified scale to indicate the number that best matches your response to each statement (Lin et al, 2005)". Participants will be asked to rate the rich and the poor on the following dimensions using a 7-point Likert scale: cold/warmth, unfriendly/friendly, incompetent/competent, incapable/capable (Kervyn, et al., 2013; Fiske, et al., 2007).

hypothesis.value:
AIM: Replicate previous findings that associate low-income groups with poor diets (Link to previous preregistration: https://osf.io/cxasd).

Hypothesis 1: Participants will show a strong association between low (vs. high) social class individuals and high calorie food using the IAT.

Hypothesis 2: Participants will report low (vs. high) social class individuals as eating more unhealthy foods in explicit measures

Hypothesis 3: Participants will attribute less competence to low (vs. high) social class in explicit measures.

Hypothesis 4: Classist stereotypes, operationalized as low social class groups having less competence using an explicit measure, will be associated with Hypothesis 1 IAT d scores.

attributes.title: Research Paper
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: In the Canadian Indigenous community, is there a relationship between self perceived mental health and interest/ involvement in traditional activities?

dataCollectionDates.value: Data collection began in 2012, the expected end date of this project is April 2020.

question2a.value: This is a correlational study, variables are listed below.

question2b.value:
Variable 1: Perceived Mental Health- as assessed in the Aboriginal Peoples Survey, 2012 Canada, Variable MH_01G: Mental health - Self-perceived.

Variable 2: Involvement in Traditional Activities- Perceived Mental Health- as assessed in the Aboriginal Peoples Survey, 2012 Canada, Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year.

question10b.value:
Data from the APS Canada 2012, will be used to compare participants responses to two items on this survey. These items are:
i) Variable MH_01G: Mental health - Self-perceived
ii) Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year

These variables will be acquired randomly from 40 participants who completed the APS in 2012 (performed by random number generation). Experimenters gathering data on one variable will be blind to participants responses on the other variable (one experimenter will collect data for variable one and a different experimenter will collect data for variable two). 
Once data has been collected a correlation will be performed using SPSS to determine whether there is a positive correlation between these variables.

question4b.value: All participants must be 15 years and older, the inclusion of younger children may skew data as these activities require a certain level of physical and mental development. Traditional activities include the following: making clothing or footwear; making arts or crafts; hunting, fishing or trapping; gathering wild plants.

question5b.value:
Data was collected using the 2012 Aboriginal Peoples Survey (APS), a national survey of indigenous people living off reserve in all Canadian provinces and territories. 

It is self reported, census data and was collected by Statistics Canada in 2012.

question6b.value:
Will be using the psychology standard of 80% power, d=.42.
See G*Power protocol for details. 
We will aim for a sample size of n=40.

question7b.value: Data termination date will be April 1st, 2020.

data.name: Power Analysis to Determine Sample Size Needed for 80.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Power Analysis to Determine Sample Size Needed for 80.docx

question8b.value:
a) Participants who responded 'Skip', 'Don't know', or 'Refuse to answer' to either variable will be excluded from the study.
b) NA
c) Participants under the age of 15 will be excluded
d) NA
e) NA

question9b.value: Once 40 participants (sample size as determined by power analysis) have been randomly extracted from 2012 APS.

question6c.value: Only one main test ( a correlation) is being performed. Tukey's HSD will be used as a post hoc test.

question7c.value: Missing data should not be an issue as only participants who responded to both variables on the APS will b e considered for random selection in the study.

question1a.value: 1. We hypothesize that there is a positive relationship between perceived mental health and involvement in traditional activities among the indigenous peoples of Canada. That is, we predict higher levels of perceived mental health among indigenous peoples who partake in more traditional activities.

question2a.value: We do not expect an interaction.

question3a.value: No variable manipulations will take place. This study relies on self report data from participants daily life.

question5a.value:
Due to  the historical indiscretions against the indigenous peoples of Canada (genocide, forced sterilization, residential schools and so forth), the Canadian government has implemented a reconciliation process to take steps to make amends with, listen to, help support and build stronger relationships with the indigenous communities. Part of the reconciliation process focuses on confronting trauma, improving mental health and supporting mental wellness in indigenous communities (Boksa et al., 2015). Traditional activities which align with indigenous peoples beliefs and values have been suggested as possible forms of treatment for mental well being (Stewart, 2008). If traditional activities are linked to improved mental health and well being, we predict that people who spend more time performing these activities may report higher levels of perceived mental health. 

References

Boksa, P., Joober, R., & Kirmayer, L. J. (2015). Mental wellness in Canada’s Aboriginal communities: striving toward reconciliation. Journal of psychiatry & neuroscience, 40(6), 363-365.

Stewart, S. L. (2008). Promoting Indigenous mental health: Cultural perspectives on healing from Native counsellors in Canada. International Journal of Health Promotion and Education, 46(2), 49-56.

question6a.value:
From the perspective that for indigenous peoples, there is a link between traditional activities and improved mental well being, then we predict that indigenous peoples who partake in traditional activities will have higher self reported mental health compared to those who do not partake. 
If this perspective is false and indigenous peoples' mental well being is not impacted by involvement in traditional activities then we predict no relationship would be found between perceived mental health and involvement in traditional activities.

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Data from the APS Canada 2012, will be used to compare participants responses to two items on this survey. These items are:
i) Variable MH_01G: Mental health - Self-perceived
ii) Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year

These variables will be acquired randomly from 40 participants who completed the APS in 2012 (performed by random number generation). Experimenters gathering data on one variable will be blind to participants responses on the other variable (one experimenter will collect data for variable one and a different experimenter will collect data for variable two). 
Once data has been collected a correlation will be performed using SPSS to determine whether there is a positive correlation between these variables.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
i) Variable MH_01G: Mental health - Self-perceived. 
This variable is answered in a questionnaire with the following possible responses:
Q:In general, would you say your health is... ?
1) Poor, 2) Fair, 3) Good, 4) Very Good, 5) Excellent

ii) Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year
This variable is answered in a questionnaire with the following possible responses:
Q: Have you done any traditional activities  in the past year?
1) Did one or more traditional activities in the past year
2) Did not do any traditional activities in the past year

A correlation will be performed to determine whether there is a relationship between these variables. The variables in the correlation will be Variable MH_01G: Mental health - Self-perceived and Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year.

This is a correlation so there is no specific IV or DV. We are determining whether Variable MH_01G: Mental health - Self-perceived and Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year co-vary together.
No covariates were used besides the two variables being tested.
Using null hypothesis testing.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: All participants must be 15 years and older, the inclusion of younger children may skew data as these activities require a certain level of physical and mental development. Traditional activities include the following: making clothing or footwear; making arts or crafts; hunting, fishing or trapping; gathering wild plants.

Data was collected using the 2012 Aboriginal Peoples Survey (APS), a national survey of indigenous people living off reserve in all Canadian provinces and territories. 

It is self reported, census data and was collected by Statistics Canada in 2012.

Will be using the psychology standard of 80% power, d=.42.
See G*Power protocol for details. 
We will aim for a sample size of n=40.
Data termination date will be April 1st, 2020.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
a) Participants who responded 'Skip', 'Don't know', or 'Refuse to answer' to either variable will be excluded from the study.
b) NA
c) Participants under the age of 15 will be excluded
d) NA
e) NA

This variable is answered in a questionnaire with the following possible responses:
Q:In general, would you say your health is... ?
1) Poor, 2) Fair, 3) Good, 4) Very Good, 5) Excellent

ii) Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year
This variable is answered in a questionnaire with the following possible responses:
Q: Have you done any traditional activities  in the past year?
1) Did one or more traditional activities in the past year
2) Did not do any traditional activities in the past year

A correlation will be performed to determine whether there is a relationship between these variables. The variables in the correlation will be Variable MH_01G: Mental health - Self-perceived and Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year.

This is a correlation so there is no specific IV or DV. We are determining whether Variable MH_01G: Mental health - Self-perceived and Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year co-vary together.
No covariates were used besides the two variables being tested.
Using null hypothesis testing.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: All participants must be 15 years and older, the inclusion of younger children may skew data as these activities require a certain level of physical and mental development. Traditional activities include the following: making clothing or footwear; making arts or crafts; hunting, fishing or trapping; gathering wild plants.

Data was collected using the 2012 Aboriginal Peoples Survey (APS), a national survey of indigenous people living off reserve in all Canadian provinces and territories. 

It is self reported, census data and was collected by Statistics Canada in 2012.

Will be using the psychology standard of 80% power, d=.42.
See G*Power protocol for details. 
We will aim for a sample size of n=40.
Data termination date will be April 1st, 2020.

Data from the APS Canada 2012, will be used to compare participants responses to two items on this survey. These items are:
i) Variable MH_01G: Mental health - Self-perceived
ii) Variable DTRACTYR: DV - Traditional activities done - Past year

question1a.value: 1. We hypothesize that there is a positive relationship between perceived mental health and involvement in traditional activities among the indigenous peoples of Canada. That is, we predict higher levels of perceived mental health among indigenous peoples who partake in more traditional activities.

question2a.value: We do not expect an interaction.

question3a.value: No variable manipulations will take place. This study relies on self report data from participants daily life.

question5a.value:
Due to  the historical indiscretions against the indigenous peoples of Canada (genocide, forced sterilization, residential schools and so forth), the Canadian government has implemented a reconciliation process to take steps to make amends with, listen to, help support and build stronger relationships with the indigenous communities. Part of the reconciliation process focuses on confronting trauma, improving mental health and supporting mental wellness in indigenous communities (Boksa et al., 2015). Traditional activities which align with indigenous peoples beliefs and values have been suggested as possible forms of treatment for mental well being (Stewart, 2008). If traditional activities are linked to improved mental health and well being, we predict that people who spend more time performing these activities may report higher levels of perceived mental health. 

References

Boksa, P., Joober, R., & Kirmayer, L. J. (2015). Mental wellness in Canada’s Aboriginal communities: striving toward reconciliation. Journal of psychiatry & neuroscience, 40(6), 363-365.

Stewart, S. L. (2008). Promoting Indigenous mental health: Cultural perspectives on healing from Native counsellors in Canada. International Journal of Health Promotion and Education, 46(2), 49-56.

question6a.value:
From the perspective that for indigenous peoples, there is a link between traditional activities and improved mental well being, then we predict that indigenous peoples who partake in traditional activities will have higher self reported mental health compared to those who do not partake. 
If this perspective is false and indigenous peoples' mental well being is not impacted by involvement in traditional activities then we predict no relationship would be found between perceived mental health and involvement in traditional activities.

attributes.title: Examining the relationship between temporal psychological distance, cultural values, and work procrastination

q1.value: Examining the relationship between temporal psychological distance, cultural values, and work procrastination

q3.value: Based on construal level theory, events that are further away in time can be seen as more abstract than events that are closer in time. This can be viewed in terms of work tasks given to an employee, and whether they choose to engage in them immediately or push away for future engagement, thus procrastinating. Previous research has shown mixed results regarding individuals perceptions of construal levels and procrastination. Cultural values and background can also impact an employees view of time. Dimensional models of culture, such as that of Trompenaars and Hampden-Turner (1998), indicate that time is seen as more flexible in collectivist vs individualist cultures, and this may influence how individuals approach their work tasks. Previous cross cultural research has shown mixed results regarding procrastination. For the current study, we will investigate if employees perception of temporal distance or cultural values better explain work procrastination.

q4.value:
H1: There is a positive relationship between scores in action identification and consideration of future consequences (directional).
H2: People with high scores in consideration of future consequences have lower scores in procrastination (directional).
H3: Scores in procrastination are lower based on scores in cultural values:
	H3A: People with high scores in cultural value of uncertainty avoidance have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
	H3B:  People with high scores in cultural value of individualism have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
        H3C:  People with high scores in cultural value of masculinity have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
H4: Scores in procrastination are lower based on scores in cultural values and consideration of future consequences:
	H4A: People with high scores in cultural value of uncertainty avoidance and high scores in consideration of future consequences have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
	H4B:  People with high scores in cultural value of individualism and high scores in consideration of future consequences have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
        H4C:  People with high scores in cultural value of masculinity and high scores in consideration of future consequences have lower scores in procrastination (directional)

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between groups, cross-sectional survey with three independent variables (action identification, consideration of future consequences, cultural values) and one dependent variable (work procrastination).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The study will utilize a web based survey that will be distributed to contacts within the working population of the USA, Sweden, and Malaysia. Participation in the study is voluntary and there is no compensation. Data collection starts on March 2, 2020 and is to be finished by April 15, 2020.

q13.value: For a powerful study, the sample size should be a minimum of 164 participants.

question.value: There are three measured IV (action identification, consideration of future consequences, cultural values) and one measured DV (work procrastination). We will measure action identification utilizing the Behavioral Identification Form (BIF; Vallacher and Wegner, 1989), consideration of future consequences utilizing the Considerations of Future Consequences scale (CFC; Strathman, Gleicher, Boninger, and Edwards, 1994), and cultural values utilizing the Individual Cultural Values scale (CVScale; Yoo, Donthu, and Lenartowicz, 2011). Procrastination at work will be measured utilizing the Irrational Procrastination Scale (IPS; Steel, 2010).

H1: Correlation (Pearson's r)
H2: Independent t-test and multiple regression
H3A: Independent t-test and multiple regression
H3B:  Independent t-test and multiple regression
H3C: Independent t-test and multiple regression
H4A: Indepedent factorial ANOVA and multiple regression
H4B: Indepedent factorial ANOVA and multiple regression
H4C: Indepedent factorial ANOVA and multiple regression

q25.value:
Trompenaars, A., and Hampden-Turner, C. (1998). Riding the waves of culture: Understanding cultural diversity in global business. New York: McGraw Hill.

Vallacher, R. R., and Wegner, D. M. (1989). Levels of personal agency: Individual variation in action identification. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 57(4), 660–671.

Strathman, A., Gleicher, F., Boninger, D. S., and Edwards, C. S. (1994). The consideration of future consequences: Weighing immediate and distant outcomes of behavior. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 66(4), 742-752.

registration_responses.q1: Examining the relationship between temporal psychological distance, cultural values, and work procrastination
registration_responses.q3: Based on construal level theory, events that are further away in time can be seen as more abstract than events that are closer in time. This can be viewed in terms of work tasks given to an employee, and whether they choose to engage in them immediately or push away for future engagement, thus procrastinating. Previous research has shown mixed results regarding individuals perceptions of construal levels and procrastination. Cultural values and background can also impact an employees view of time. Dimensional models of culture, such as that of Trompenaars and Hampden-Turner (1998), indicate that time is seen as more flexible in collectivist vs individualist cultures, and this may influence how individuals approach their work tasks. Previous cross cultural research has shown mixed results regarding procrastination. For the current study, we will investigate if employees perception of temporal distance or cultural values better explain work procrastination.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: There is a positive relationship between scores in action identification and consideration of future consequences (directional).
H2: People with high scores in consideration of future consequences have lower scores in procrastination (directional).
H3: Scores in procrastination are lower based on scores in cultural values:
	H3A: People with high scores in cultural value of uncertainty avoidance have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
	H3B:  People with high scores in cultural value of individualism have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
        H3C:  People with high scores in cultural value of masculinity have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
H4: Scores in procrastination are lower based on scores in cultural values and consideration of future consequences:
	H4A: People with high scores in cultural value of uncertainty avoidance and high scores in consideration of future consequences have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
	H4B:  People with high scores in cultural value of individualism and high scores in consideration of future consequences have lower scores in procrastination (directional)
        H4C:  People with high scores in cultural value of masculinity and high scores in consideration of future consequences have lower scores in procrastination (directional)

registration_responses.q8.question: Between groups, cross-sectional survey with three independent variables (action identification, consideration of future consequences, cultural values) and one dependent variable (work procrastination).
registration_responses.q12.question: The study will utilize a web based survey that will be distributed to contacts within the working population of the USA, Sweden, and Malaysia. Participation in the study is voluntary and there is no compensation. Data collection starts on March 2, 2020 and is to be finished by April 15, 2020.
registration_responses.q17.question: There are three measured IV (action identification, consideration of future consequences, cultural values) and one measured DV (work procrastination). We will measure action identification utilizing the Behavioral Identification Form (BIF; Vallacher and Wegner, 1989), consideration of future consequences utilizing the Considerations of Future Consequences scale (CFC; Strathman, Gleicher, Boninger, and Edwards, 1994), and cultural values utilizing the Individual Cultural Values scale (CVScale; Yoo, Donthu, and Lenartowicz, 2011). Procrastination at work will be measured utilizing the Irrational Procrastination Scale (IPS; Steel, 2010).
